titleStmt.title: Tattooing Harran
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to the location of the SHAWI media assets.

spanGrp.span: In the past, there was no electricity and so we brought a kerosene lamp. There was the kerosene in the lamp and it had a wick like this. We left it and put it on a shelf like this.
And then we started making It produced soot and made a lot of smoke. Smoke, smoke, smoke until it became glowing soot.
It made so much smoke and then its glowing soot accumulated (in the wick); the dirt from its smoke.
We took and brought it and then we put the gall of a ewe on it; we put it on that smoke, on the the glowing soot.
And we brought a little bit of indigo, a little bit of aloe vera and put everything on it. Then we took three needles, we took three needles and joined them together.
And then we started to make the drawing, we made a sketch on we made it and it looked like yoghurt.
So, we made first the drawing and then we hit it with the needle, we stitched it with the needle until she began to bleed.
When the blood emerged we stopped. We stopped (stitching) when blood emerged, when the blood had all come out (from the place of the tattoo).
When the blood emerged we stopped the tattooing, we left it. It remained swollen for two or three days. After two or three days it became blue. Blue like indigo.
For the whole life (of the person) it does not disappear; even when we die and when our bones get rotten it does not disappear.
It never disappears from that person. No paint or anything is like this; it does never disappear.
It remains like this, it remains on the bone. It is said that even the bones get blue. | Doesn’t it hurt?
No. Actually at the beginning it hurts, but then it does not hurt. At the beginning in swells and hurts and blood emerges. | How many days does it take until the colour comes out?
It takes a day. In the morning the colour emerges. When I stitch it in the evening, the colour appears in the morning, it comes out in the morning.
In the morning it has become blue, but it remains swollen for a day or two. And the spot of the needles is hurting.
We prepare (lit. cook) the flesh with the needles. | Yes. | Until it does never ever diappear.
It is said, even the doctors say, “Even your veins and your bones have become blue.” | Incredible!
Yes. It is said that the colour of the flesh goes under it where it also remains blue.
They also make tattoos on their necks, they make tattoos on their thingy, on their breasts. They make tattoos; we, the old women.
